As we passed through Slateford, he spoke of Dr. Belfrage, his great-hearted friend, of his obligations to him, and of his son, my friend, both lying to· gether in Colinton churchyard3 andos Dr. Dick, who was minister before him, of the Coventrys, and of Stitchel and Sprouston, of his mother, and of himself—his doubts of his own sincerity in reli- gion, his sense of sin, of God-reverting often to his dying friend. »Such a thing only occurred to me with him once or twice all my life3 and then when we were home, he was silent, shut up, self-con- tained as before.
